description.narrative: Community-level institutions improve the use of safe water, hand washing with soap and use of latrines by children and families though promotion of good hygiene practices and meeting of WASH infrastructure standards.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Community-level institutions improve the use of safe water, hand washing with soap and use of latrines by children and families though promotion of good hygiene practices and meeting of WASH infrastructure standards.

description.narrative: In 2019, 630 schools and 121 health centres were certified one Star and promote behaviour change and create demand. This represents 13% out of all schools and 14% out of all health centres in the targeted 10 regions. 11 schools and 20 health centres received 3 Star certification for having reached basic WASH services and meeting national standards. Menstrual Hygiene Management activities were integrated into the curricula of 1,367 schools, and 226 out of 1,000 planned schools have implemented MHM activities. In total almost 130,000 children including 63,000 girls benefited from UNICEF WASH program in Institutions. | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:31/12/2019

title.narrative: Number of schools with access to basic WASH service in the reporting year only, with UNICEF direct support
